editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Pre≈øaging his Maje≈øties Exaltation to future Honour and Greatne≈øs Tran≈øcending not only the mo≈øt potent Chri≈øtian Princes in Europe, but by Divine de≈øignment ordained to be the mo≈øt Mighty Monarch in the ∆≤niver≈øe: Never any Star having appeared before at the birth of any (the Highe≈øt humane Hero) except our Saviour.

div.head: To the mo≈øt Augu≈øtuous Prince my Dear and Dread Soveraign Charlemain the 2d. by the Mercy and Divine decree of the Almighty, his Highne≈øs own Inhaerent Inheritance, and legal Succe≈ø≈øion, The peoples ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing de≈øire, ≈øignal Loyalty, longing affection, and e≈øpecial Election, of Great Britain, France, and Ireland, Jure Divino & humano, King Defender of the true ancient Chri≈øtian Catholick Faith, &c. And by Divine Providence preordained to be the mo≈øt pious, prudent and potent Prince in the Univer≈øe.
div.p:
ERuctavit Cor meum verbum bonum; Dico ego opera mea Regi, P≈øal. 45.1. My heart is Inditing of a good matter, concerning
the King; Divine providence di≈øpo≈øing my Meditations towards ≈øo ≈øacred a ≈øubject, directs the Dedication thereof according to the Princely Prophet Davids pattern. Dico opera mea Regi. Quod au≈øus ≈øum tantae Maje≈øtatis Principem tantillo adire munu≈øculo That ≈øo mean a per≈øon ≈øhould approach the pre≈øence of ≈øo mighty a Prince, with ≈øo poor a pre≈øent may be accounted high pre≈øumption; yet 'tis ≈øtoried, that Jupiter was plea≈øed with the cour≈øe fare of a poor per≈øon.

∆≤nder the law he that had not a Lamb to ≈øacrifice, was permitted
to offer a Turtle Dove, or pair of young Pigeons, and in the Go≈øpel a ≈ømall Mite renders a poor Widdow Liberall, Ae≈øchines when he ≈øaw his fellow Schollers pre≈øenting great gifts to Socrates their Ma≈øter, being de≈øtitute of ≈øuch a pre≈øent, pre≈øented him≈øelf, profe≈ø≈øing to be wholy devoted to his Ma≈øter, which Socrates accepted as the chiefe≈øt Gift. There is nothing worth your Maje≈øties acceptance in the power of Your Highne≈ø≈øe meane≈øt ≈øubject, Para≈øitical adulation I know unplea≈øing to your prudent Maje≈øty, and hateful to mine own Nature, my Life and what el≈øe can be accounted dear

que ad aras, I have bin alwaies and ≈øtill ≈øhall be mo≈øt freely ready to ≈øacrifice. 'Tis ≈øaid of Cae≈ø ‚Ä¢ r that ≈øurely nature meant him for a Conqueror, when ≈øhe gave him both ≈øuch courage and ≈øuch courte≈øie which put Marius into a muze (≈øaying) that he that du ‚Ä¢ ≈øt ≈øpeak to him, was ignorant of his greatne≈ø≈øe, and he that dur≈øt not was ≈øo of his goodne≈ø≈øe.

The incomparable Candor of your Maje≈øties ≈øweete≈øt di≈øpo≈øition gives me incouragement humbly to implore Your Maje≈øties princely pardon for this pre≈øumption, and to vouch≈øafe your Highne≈ø≈øe Gracious acceptance of this unpoli≈øhed piece,
penner whil≈øt my Soule (though inlarged with ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing Love and Joy for my Soveraigns ≈øafe and happy Re≈øtoration, (for which my prayers to Heaven were frequent and con≈øtant, my Tounge and Pen Head, Heart, and Hands according to my be≈øt ability not wanting) yet was much ≈øtreightned with perplexity of ≈øpirit, by rea≈øon of long impri≈øonment and di≈øtracted with di≈øtemper of Mind and E≈øtate alwaies attending the ≈øad Condition of Pri≈øoners! Happily herein ≈øomewhat not unworthy your Maje≈øties ≈øerious con≈øideration at pre≈øent) may be ob≈øerved: & I hope I have herein delivered
nothing touching your Maje≈øty but what I have received from the dictates of that Good Divine ≈øpirit which hath directed me through this whole di≈øcour≈øe and what I faithfully believe will in due time be fully accompli≈øhed, my faith herein being in part confirmed not only by tho≈øe propheticall pre≈øages in this Tract ≈øpecified, and by Dreams & Vi≈øions (which how≈øoever by ≈øome may be accounted vain or deceitful) yet I have often proved, & ≈øince found really to come to pa≈øs, and receive a plenary effect touching your Maje≈øties return and other matters of Moment: But al≈øo by an irre≈øi≈øtible and invincible pre≈ø≈øure of ≈øpirit, to publi≈øh
what in this tract, I have written; ≈øo that I may truly ≈øay with the Prophet Jeremiah, 'Twas a fire in my bones, and I could not ≈øupre≈ø≈øe it, but by Divine impul≈øion of ≈øpirit, was importuned and pre≈øt to declare what by divine de≈øignment I believe is determined touching your Maje≈øties exaltation not only to be the mo≈øt potent Chri≈øtian Prince in Europe, But to be the phenix of this Age, and the mo≈øt Famous and Illu≈øtrious potentate in the ∆≤niver≈øe. This I ≈øhall be ready to avouch again≈øt the mo≈øt criticall carpers murmuring and detracting Momu≈ø≈øes, and ≈øeeming zealous Zoylu≈ø≈øes; and 'tis probable ≈øome pernicious Pa≈øhurs
wil con≈øpire with other confederates cogitare cogitationes to devi≈øe devi≈øes again≈øt Jeremiah and be ready percutere eum lingua, to ≈ømite him with the tongue, Jer. 18.18. Their malice ≈øhall render them nothing more then Pa≈øhurs reward, but a new name of terror and ≈øhame, Magor mi≈ø≈øabib ≈øignifying fear round about, we have of late unhappily had too many pa≈øhurs who cannot abide to hear any truth ≈øpoken, ≈øuch as wil not hear any good declared or pro≈øperity pre≈øaged to their Prince, how pious & worthy ≈øoever, but are ready rather to calumniate; let all ≈øuch ≈øeditions Shebaes, Cur≈øing Shimei's, Railing Rab≈øhekeis,
& rebellious Korahs know, that though they rail & rage, again≈øt their lawful Soveraign again≈øt whom they ought not to entertain ≈øo much as an evil thought, he that ≈øits in Heaven will not only deride but in the end de≈øtroy all ≈øuch di≈øturbing Traytors, & will e≈øtabli≈øh your Maje≈øties Throne in righteou≈øne≈øs, cau≈øe your Highne≈ø≈øe Crown to flouri≈øh and cloth your Enemies with ≈øhame & confu≈øion in conclu≈øion. The King of Kings hath ≈øet his King on high upon his holy Hill, his Sion, over his People; & ≈øent an heavenly Herald to proclaim his pre≈øent power, and declare a future inlargement of his Dominion; A glorious Star, or rather „Äà1 page missing„Äâ
flial Con≈øtellation, the Pleiades Charles Waine, ≈øhining brightlie on the day of your Maje≈øties Nativity, when your Maje≈øties late pious Father of ble≈øsed memory came to offer his ≈øacri≈øice of prai≈øe as Incen≈øe at the Alter of St. Paul. That Cele≈øtiall Emba≈ø≈øadour was ≈øent to certifie Gods acceptance of that ≈øacrifice, and to confirm the certainty of your Maje≈øties future Exaltation, to tran≈øcendent honour by divine de≈øignment preordained. E Caelis tanti beneficii mittitur nunciusquia nemo in terras illius magnitudinem nec intelligebat, nec credebat (as was ≈øaid of our Saviours ≈øtar appearing upon
his Nativity) Caele≈øtium munerum merito caele≈øtis nuncius e≈øt, the people neither under≈øtanding nor believing the greatne≈ø≈øe and goodne≈ø≈øe of the benefit be≈øtowed on them, an heavenly nuntio is therefore ≈øent to a≈øsure them of both. I have wuch more to ≈øpeak concerning Your ≈øacred Maje≈øty who may well be re≈øembled to the Golden Gandle≈øtick, and the two Renowned Dukes, your Maje≈øties Royal Brethren to the two Olive Trees on the right and left ≈øide thereof Zech. 4. But lea≈øt I ≈øhould incurre the cen≈øure of the City of Myndas for making my Porch to large, I ≈øhall crave your Maje≈øties pardon, and Conclude
with the prayer of that Princely Prophet your Maje≈øties mo≈øt pious Father, I pray God ble≈øse Your Maje≈øty and e≈øtabli≈øh Your Kingdoms in righteou≈øne≈øs, your ≈øoul in true Religion, and your honour in the love of God and your People, which is and ≈øhall be the dayly and hearty prayer of

The glorious Star of King Charls II. Or, the Triumphall Charriot of the Britti≈øh Charlemaine, Charles-waine.
div.p:
ALmighty God the King of Kings, to whom the Shield and Pillars of the Earth belong, by whom Kingsraign, Princes bear rule, and Rulers have Dominion, as he is the Authour, Giver and Di≈øpo≈øer of Dignities, Honours and highe≈øt promotions; So his Divine Maje≈øty is oftentimes plea≈øed by remarkable preceding ≈øignes, to demon≈øtrate his purpo≈øe of doing great things, for tho≈øe per≈øons, whom his Omni≈øcient Wi≈øedome prede≈øtinateth to ≈øuperlative
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
Honour and Greatne≈ø≈øe. To omit Heathen Hi≈øtory, holy Writ is full and frequent in Examples of this nature, ≈øignes coele≈øtiall, by Angels, Stars, ≈øignes in the Heavens, Lightnings, Thunders, Clouds, and very frequently by fires from heaven, or bright-≈øhining lights, and flames and pillars of fires al≈øo on Earth; alwayes evident infallible pre≈øages, to per≈øons or places, publique or private of extraordinary mercies or Judgements en≈øuing.

To in≈øtance in ≈øome few (for to mention all would be too tedious) the Lord by Angels and Vi≈øions often appeared to Abraham, touching his ≈øeed and e≈øtate; ≈øo to I≈øaac and Jacob; And upon Mo≈øes his call to be Leader of the I≈øraelites out of Aegypt, the hou≈øe of Bondage; the Angel of the Lord appeared to him in a flame of fire, in a bu≈øh burning,
but not con≈øumed; Exod. 3.2. Gods mercy herein is evidenced to Mo≈øes and his people; And after Gods Judgments again≈øt their Enemies, who kept them in bondage, is manife≈øted by many miracles, ≈øhewed by the power of God in the hand of Mo≈øes, Exod: 9.23. who (inter alia) ≈øtretching out his rod towards heaven, The Lord ≈øendeth haile, mingled with fire, thunder and lightning on man and bea≈øt.
The I≈øraelites marching out of Aegypt, the Lord goeth before them, by day in a Pillar of a Cloud, and by night in a Pillar of Fire, Exod. 13.21.
Aaron ≈øpeaking to the Congregation of I≈ørael, the glory of the Lord appeareth in a cloud towards the Wilderne≈ø≈øe, Exod. 16.10.

Mo≈øes coming down from mount Sinai, with the two Tables in his hand, his Face ≈øhineth ≈øo
bright, that Aaron and the people are afraid to come neer him, Exod. 34.30.
On the third day before giving of the law, thunder, lightning, thick Clouds, and the mount Sinai trembling, &c. Exod. 19.16.

An Angel of the Lord appeared to Manoah and his wife, predicting the Conception and Birth of Samp≈øon, and they offering Sacrifice, the Angel a≈øcended in the flame which came from the Altar, Judges 13. A wonderfull ≈øigne pre≈øaging Samp≈øons ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing ≈øtrength, to be given of God; and therefore tis ≈øaid when he ≈øhewed any Acts of his valour and force, The ≈øpirit of the Lord came mightily upon him, Jud. 14.6.15.14.

The Angel Gabriel was ≈øent of God, to declare to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary her Conception and birth of our Saviour, and give him the
name Je≈øus, and prenunciate his goodne≈øs and greatne≈øs, Mat. 1.21. Luke 1, 31.32. A Saviour of the people, and he ≈øhall be great, and called the ≈øon of the mo≈øt high, &c.

After his birth, there appeared a Star, by which the Magi, the great wealthy and wi≈øemen of the Ea≈øt were directed to Chri≈øt, who came and wor≈øhipped, and pre≈øented rich gifts, Gold, Frankincen≈øe, and Myrrhe, &c. Mat. 2.11.

On the Birth-day of our Soveraign Lord the King, being Saturday 29. of May, 1630. a bright ≈øtar at noon ≈øhone gloriou≈øly in the heavens, his late Maje≈øty coming then to hear a Sermon at St. Pauls Cro≈ø≈øe; the Text whereof was, Samp≈øons Probleme or riddle, Jud. 14, 14. Out of the strong came forth ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, &c. And to pre≈øent his prai≈øe & peace-Offering at St. Paul's Altar, for the Royall Queens happy delivery of our then hopefull Prince: our now
mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed, loved and honoured, King, Charlemaine, the II. from a plain but happily prophetical Pen; this threefold di≈øtichon then dropped.

lg.l: While≈øt to the Altar of St. Paul the King
Approached with his gratefull Offering:
A Star at noon appeared; tell me divine?
That preache≈øt Riddles, why it then did ≈øhine?
To the We≈øtern world a Prince is newly born;
And the Ea≈øt too morrow in Ecclip≈øe ≈øhall mourn.

div.p: That there was on the day following being Sunday, an Orientall Ecclip≈øe cannot be doubted; The effects and operation of which are yet in future to be produced, of which ≈øomething ≈øhall be ≈øaid hereafter.

At the death of Julius Cae≈øar, Qui in Deorum numerum relatus e≈øt, who was numbred among the Gods, a Comet ≈øhined then for ≈øeven dayes together, ari≈øing about the eleventh houre of the day, which by the blinde Heathens was believed to be Cae≈øars ≈øoul, who had been a Comet of Combu≈øtion to the World,
Horace lib. 1. ode 12.
‚Äî micat inter omnes
Julium ≈øidus, velut inter ignes
Luna minores.

But what Hi≈øtory do we finde mentioning the Apparition of any cele≈øtial ≈øigne or ≈øtar, at the Birth of any the greate≈øt per≈øons before or ≈øince our Saviour? Surely, none of our highe≈øt humane Hero's have been honoured herewith; but our Sacred Soveraign, upon who≈øe Nativity in the mid-day, in the face of the Sun this Star appeared, and ≈øhined mo≈øt brightly, in the fight of many of good credit, yet living to te≈øtifie the Truth hereof.

Let none maliciou≈øly mi≈øtake me, as though I compared our King with the worlds Saviour, far be it from even my imaginations, much more expre≈ø≈øions; I know his Maje≈øty as much abominates prophane adoration, as he hates para≈øitical Adulation: I ≈øhall therefore
onely ≈øet down ≈øome brief but ≈øerious ob≈øervations of re≈øemblance happening touching that Star, appearing at the Nativity of our Saviour, and this Star or ≈øigne C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
le≈øtiall ≈øhining at the Nativity of our Soveraign, and leave the ≈øignification, interpretation and amplification thereof to ≈øome diviner Pens.

The fir≈øt Ob≈øervation, is, that as that Star did lead the wi≈øemen to Chri≈øt to wor≈øhip his divine Maje≈øty, ≈øo the wi≈øer and better ≈øort of men were directed by divine Providence to yield due honour and obedience to our rightfull Soveraigne Lord and King, which by wilfully wicked per≈øons was long withdrawn and denyed.

The ≈øecond, That as Chri≈øt Je≈øus was the worlds coele≈øtiall and eternal Saviour, ≈øent into the world
to ≈øave his people from their ≈øins, and Death & Hell due for the ≈øame, and therefore had the ≈øweet name Je≈øus given him by the Angel from God: So hath God ≈øent our Soveraign King to be a Terre≈øtial, temporal Savior to our Microcro≈øm; the≈øe three Nations, ready to ≈øinck in mi≈øery & ≈ølavery, and to be ≈øwallowed up by divelli≈øhly minded Mi≈øcreants, Rebellious Traitors, walking craftily, &c. Such as Jerewiah the Prophet mentions, chap. 6.28.

But God hath made our King as tis ≈øaid, v. 27. of that Chapter; I have ≈øet thee for a Tower and a Fortre≈ø≈øe among my people, &c. And chap. 15.20. I will make thee unto this people, a fenced brazen wall, though they fight against thee, they ≈øhall not prevaile; for I am with thee to ≈øave thee, and to deliver thee, ≈øaith the Lords.

Thirdly, as the wi≈øemen of the
Ea≈øt ≈øeeing the Star, came to Chri≈øt, and rejoyced with great joy, and fell down and wor≈øhipped him, and opened their Trea≈øures, and pre≈øented to him Gold, Incen≈øe and Myrrhe, Mat. 2.10, 11. So hath the Lord touched and wonderfully inclined the hearts of the people towards our gracious King, that with inexpre≈ø≈øible joy, and ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing affection, they bow and ≈øubmit to his Maje≈øty, with rich Pre≈øents, in token of Love, Loyalty and Homage: As the prophetical King, and Kingly Prophet David, of our Saviour prophe≈øied; The Daughter of Tyre ≈øhall be there with a gift, like as the rich al≈øo among the people ≈øhall doe hommage before thy face, with pre≈øents. P≈øal. 45.12. Is not this Scripture fulfilled at this time in our ≈øight? Again, P≈øal. 68.29. Kings ≈øhall bring pre≈øents unto thee, the Kings of Arabia and Saba ≈øhall bring gifts, &c. This is in part fulfilled
by the King of Spaines Royall and kinde Prefents, &c. But will hereafter be more fully accompli≈øhed, but by whom and in what manner, the ≈øame ≈øhall be done (although I have good ground for my Faith herein) I ≈øhall at pre≈øent conceale, another opportunity happily for di≈øcovery hereof may be fitter.

Many propheticall expre≈ø≈øions in holy Writ might be produced; properly appliable to our Soveraign, King Charls, and even parallel to the pre≈øent times and occa≈øions, a ≈øhort Tract whereof hath been penned a year ≈øince, but not yet publi≈øhed; which I now forbear to ≈øpecifie, intending onely at pre≈øent to ≈øpeak and write of the ≈øaid Stars Apparition at his Maje≈øties Nativity, and ob≈øervations thereupon.

Yet thus much, I crave leave to ≈øay (I tru≈øt without offence to God or good men) and propo≈øe this quare; What man, ever more like
the Son of man our Saviour, in his humanity, then this our Sacred King in ≈øeveral re≈øpects, as he was:

1. (In his own per≈øon) born to be a King: 2 Pointed at by an extraordinary Star: 3. His late Maje≈øty in a Letter of Advi≈øe to the then Prince of Wales, our now mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed King, hath in many re≈øpects manife≈øted him≈øelf
to be a mo≈øt wi≈øe, and prudent Prince, by his political in≈øtructions in State Affaires; a mo≈øt pious Prie≈øt and Eccle≈øia≈øtes in his divine Doctrines and directions, and a true Prophet, in his infallible predictions, the particulars whereof, as it would require much time to recite, expre≈ø≈øe and apply, ≈øo, (I doubt) it would be accounted more tedious, then requi≈øitely nece≈ø≈øary to repeat the ≈øame, being already ≈øet down mo≈øt fully and eminent for ob≈øervation in that un; parrallel'd piece „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ .

I ≈øhall onely mention briefly from his late Maje≈øty Charls le ≈øag and le bon, the mirrour of piety, patience and prudence, ≈øome few precepts or pre≈øcriptions of advi≈øe to prayers for, and prophecies touching his now mo≈øt hopefull and happy Maje≈øty.

Touching Afflictions, Religion
and Re≈øolution in all conditions; a Crown upon ≈øordid di≈øhonourable irreligious terms is not worth taking up, or enjoying: Keep you to true principles of piety, virtue and bonour, you ≈øhall never want a kingdome.
Thus by our late Maje≈øty of ble≈ø≈øed memory, to our now renowned King was it written, concerning, trouble and affliction, whereby to gain wi≈ødom in youth.
